articles.title: Bayelsa gov urges joint action against ocean rise threat

articles.summary: Douye Diri spoke at the Ocean Rise and Coastal Resilience Summit in Nice, France, on Saturday. The event is a precursor to the third United Nations Ocean Conference scheduled for June 9 to June 13. Diri's delegation included the Speaker of the Bayelsa State House of Assembly, Abraham Ingobere, President of the Ijaw National Congress, Prof Benjamin Okaba and the Commissioner for Marine and Blue Economy, Faith Zibs-Godwin.

articles.title: Earth is burning up — it's time for us to grow up as a species and start to take action
articles.author: Rethabile Masilo
articles.summary: The northern hemisphere is getting warmer. The city of Paris has reached 24°C afternoons. Robert Frost's Nothing Gold Can Stay reminds us that nature's first green is gold. Human activity has been pumping greenhouse gases into the atmosphere, which traps heat and is slowly warming the planet.

articles.title: Curious kids: Cold mountains, hot air — it's all about pressure
articles.author: James Renwick
articles.summary: A climate scientist explains how the sun heats Earth, which warms the air that rises and immediately begins to cool as it loses pressure. Ollie, 8, from Christchurch, New Zealand is wondering why it gets colder as you climb up mountains. It's because the atmosphere is moving into the cooler layers.

articles.title: Draft climate plan proposes hundreds of actions to protect Northern Ireland
articles.author: Rebecca Black
articles.summary: Hundreds of actions are being considered in the latest proposed plan to tackle climate change in Northern Ireland. The draft third Northern Ireland climate change adaptation programme (NICCAP3) includes more than 250 actions suggested by government departments, councils, academia, NGOs, businesses and the public. An eight-week public consultation will gather views on the proposals.

articles.summary: There are wildfires raging in British Columbia, northwestern Ontario, northern Quebec, plus Newfoundland and Labrador. Canada's most costly disaster was a wildfire which consumed part of Fort McMurray, home to Alberta's tar sands (Canada's largest petroleum resource) in 2016. In Canada, petroleum production is responsible for 31% of national carbon emissions. The next big source of emissions is transportation, which is 22% of Canada's total. Canadians are among the world's highest emitters of carbon.

articles.title: Uranus' Color Change: 168-Year Time-Lapse
articles.author: Alexandra Hartman
articles.summary: The University of Oxford has released an animated visualization showing the cyclical changes our planet undergoes each year. It's a great visual aid for understanding complex climate topics. According to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the warmest eight years on record have all occurred as 2015, emphasizing the increasing importance of understanding seasonal changes.

articles.title: Our planet's oxygen levels will drop, and there's no way to stop it
articles.author: New Scientist
articles.summary: It's no secret that Earth is going to be uninhabitable billions of years from now, when the oxygen levels on the planet drop and life as we know it stops. The factors resulting in dropping oxygen levels are complex, but human-driven climate change could play a large role in the end of life on Earth.

articles.title: Our planet's oxygen levels will drop, and there's no way to stop it
articles.author: Joshua Hawkins
articles.summary: According to scientists, Earth's oxygen levels are going to drop rapidly and life as we know it will cease to exist billions of years from now. It will be similar to the Great Oxidation Event (GOE) that happened over 2.4 billion years ago. Scientists estimate that the sun will explode, effectively ending life in our solar system some 2 billion years later.

articles.title: Earth's Energy Imbalance Surges Beyond Predictions, Threatens Climate Monitoring Efforts
articles.author: R. J. Manuel
articles.summary: Earth's energy imbalance is rising at a much faster rate than climate models had predicted. Scientists warn that without proper monitoring, we could lose one of our most important tools for tracking and predicting climate change. CERES satellite instruments are nearing the end of their operational lifespans. NASA's replacement mission, called Libera, is scheduled to launch in 2027.

articles.title: What young voters want from Albanese
articles.summary: At the recent election, nearly half of all voters were Millennials or Gen Z. Their votes helped deliver Labor its biggest lower house majority ever, returned a sizable crossbench, and left the Coalition reeling. Despite their decisive influence, young voters are still waiting for answers. Climate activist Anjali Sharma asks if Labor will govern for the young people who delivered them victory.

articles.title: WFP warns of ‘dramatic' hunger in Haiti as hurricane season begins
articles.author: Jovani Davis
articles.summary: Haiti is among the five worst hunger crises globally, with 5.7 million people suffering from emergency levels of food insecurity. More than one million people have been displaced due to escalating gang violence and insecurity, especially in the capital, Port-au-Prince. WFP needs $46.4 million over the next six months to maintain its emergency operations and tackle the root causes of hunger and malnutrition. Haiti's 2025 Humanitarian Response Plan calls for over $908 million, yet only 8 percent of that total has been secured.

articles.title: Villeurbanne Archives
articles.author: Omar El-Sayed
articles.summary: There are 3,700 young trees in La Feyssine Park trying to combat the ravages of global warming and declining water tables. It's not like we've been doing it for decades, but it's better late than never.    .

articles.title: How climate change is pushing agriculture to the brink
articles.author: BKP Sinha/ Arvind Kumar Jha
articles.summary: Agriculture in India is deeply intertwined with the monsoon, which accounts for nearly 70% of the country's annual rainfall and supports over half of its cultivated land. With monsoon rains becoming less reliable, farmers are increasingly turning to groundwater to keep their crops alive. Unregulated and widespread extraction of groundwater is rapidly depleting aquifers, especially in regions already under significant water stress. The Hindu Kush Himalaya region has seen average temperatures rise by +0.28°C per decade since 1951.

articles.title: Flood Alert: Wamakko Urges Sokoto Residents To Take Precautions
articles.author: Ayobamiji Komolafe
articles.summary: Senator Aliyu Magatakarda Wamakko has urged residents of Sokoto State to take proactive measures in anticipation of possible flooding, as predicted by the Nigerian Meteorological Agency. NiMET recently raised concerns about a likely outbreak of cholera and other waterborne diseases across several Nigerian states due to anticipated heavy rainfall and flooding in 2025.

articles.title: Is THIS how the world will end? Scientists warn Earth could be flung out of orbit by a passing star...
articles.author: Shivali Best
articles.summary: In a new study, researchers from the Planetary Science Institute and the University of Bordeaux predict that Earth could be flung out of orbit by a passing star. This would leave any inhabitants - including humans - to freeze to death. However, the chances of this happening are very low. Over the next 5 billion years, the chance of Earth being flung from orbit is around one in 500.

articles.title: West Antarctic Ice Sheet is on the verge of COLLAPSING - sparking 13 feet of irreversible global sea...
articles.author: Jonathan Chadwick
articles.summary: The West Antarctic Ice Sheet contains 750,000 cubic miles of ice - enough to fill Wembley Stadium nearly 3 billion times. It is on the brink of a disastrous 'irreversible' collapse. The collapse would cause a devastating sea-level rise globally over the next few hundred years of 13 feet (4 metres). It could be triggered with ocean warming only slightly above the rate that we're seeing in the present day.

articles.title: Scientists discover 34 million year old hidden river world buried under 2 km of Antarctic ice
articles.author: TOI Trending Desk
articles.summary: The East Antarctic Ice Sheet began forming 34 million years ago, as global temperatures plummeted and CO2 levels dropped below a critical threshold. Radio-echo sounding (RES) and computer models revealed a river-carved terrain that was about the size of Wales locked under nearly two kilometers of ice. It dates back to a period when Antarctica was part of Gondwana, a supercontinent shared with Africa, South America, and Australia. The discovery could help scientists predict how the East Antarctic ice sheet could behave in a warming world.

articles.title: How many ice ages has the Earth had, and could humans live through one?
articles.author: Denise Su
articles.summary: Curious Kids is a series for children of all ages. Mason C., age 8, from Hobbs, New Mexico, has a question about ice ages. The Earth has had at least five ice ages and the most recent one started about 2.6 million years ago. The most recent interglacial period began about 11,000 years ago and lasted about 300 million years. During the last ice age, the planet was cooler than it is now and most of North America and Eurasia was covered in ice sheets. Humans have been living in North America since at least 23,000 year ago.

articles.title: Protecting a Florida Community from Gentrification
articles.summary: Census Bureau reports that West Palm Beach's population grew 8.9% between 2020 and 2024. New developments are driving up prices and making it harder for longtime residents to afford to live there. Jessica Gomez meets the people behind a concerted effort to keep one community in the hands of people who have lived there for generations.

articles.summary: How to turn down the volume and protect wildlife in your yard and garden from human-made noise. Birds, squirrels, rabbits, frogs, insects and other wildlife are affected by the noise made by humans and are very sensitive to it.

articles.author: Christopher Campbell-Duruflé
articles.summary: As wildfire season begins, the destructive impacts of climate change are being felt across Canada. 192,000 people were evacuated in 2023 due to disasters made more severe by climate change, including floods and wildfires. By 2050, more than 140 million people could become internal climate migrants in sub-Saharan Africa, South Asia and Latin America. Canada understated the reality of internal climate migration in its submissions under the 2015 Paris Agreement. Indigenous Peoples suffer from flawed adaptation policies and institutional barriers that prevent them from effectively responding to emergencies.

articles.title: Ocean heat, sea-level rise threaten communities
articles.summary: In 2024, Australia, New Zealand, many Pacific Islands, Malaysia, Indonesia, Philippines, northern Australia, eastern Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands, and southern New Zealand saw above average rainfall. Extreme rainfall and flooding caused deadly and destructive impacts across the region. The late 2024 tropical cyclone season in the Philippines was unprecedented, with 12 storms during September to November. In Indonesia, glacier ice loss continued rapidly, with the total ice area declining by 30-50 percent since 2022. The annual average sea surface temperature in 2024 was the highest in the time series since the early 1980s.

articles.title: Reforestation can't undo global warming, but it could help, study says
articles.author: Erin Blakemore
articles.summary: The scientists modeled what might happen if humans reached the planet's reforestation potential, adding about 4.6 million square miles of trees and bringing Earth's forests back to preindustrial levels. It might help cool the planet more than expected, but not enough to offset the warming since industrial times.

articles.title: Reforestation can't undo global warming, but it could help, study says
articles.author: Erin Blakemore
articles.summary: Trees' natural emissions could help cool the planet more than expected, but not enough to offset the warming since industrialization. Full reforestation is not feasible, but tree restoration may have 'higher climate change mitigation potential' than previously thought. Reforestation would have different effects in different parts of the world.

articles.title: Living ‘on shore'
articles.author: Tamoy Ashman
articles.summary: $244-million project has been completed along a 244-metre stretch of the Annotto Bay beach in St Mary, Jamaica. The beach nourishment extends 12 metres from the existing slope and protects the main road leading to the town from erosion. Residents living along the shoreline complain that little was done to protect their property and livelihoods. Demar Brown packs stones fished from the sea to protect his backyard from further erosion. O'Neil Archie has lived near the beach for more than 50 years. He is worried about the future of his home in the event of a hurricane.

articles.title: Melting Arctic ice opens shorter shipping routes, stokes worries about climate change-induced destruction
articles.summary: Shipping activity has surged in the Arctic in the last decade. With that rise comes a new environmental threat. More ships mean more fossil fuel emissions and more pollution, especially in the form of black carbon. The United Nations' International Maritime Organization has pledged to reduce shipping emissions by at least 20 per cent over the next five years.

articles.title: Map Shows US Cities That Could Go Underwater if 'Doomsday Glacier' Melts
articles.author: Joe Edwards
articles.summary: The Thwaites Glacier is responsible for about 4 percent of current global sea level rise. If the glacier were to completely melt, it could raise sea levels by more than 10 feet. In Florida, a large, southern portion of the state would be swallowed by seawater, as well as the city of Miami and Everglades National Park. Along the East Coast, a slew of major cities would be impacted by rising waters.

articles.title: WA emissions have risen but premier insists it's necessary in global fight against climate change

articles.title: Healthier to Live in a Warmer or Cooler Climate?
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Humans operate optimally at a core temperature of around 37°C (98°F). Extreme heat stresses the cardiovascular system, while extreme cold places strain on the respiratory system and increases risks like hypothermia. People in cold Nordic countries enjoy long life expectancies thanks to efficient insulation, universal healthcare, and strong social safety nets. Those in hot regions with limited infrastructure and economic challenges struggle to cope with rising heat.

articles.title: As Arctic ice vanishes, maritime traffic booms fuel climate crisis
articles.author: Lara BULLENS
articles.summary: The Arctic is warming four times faster than anywhere else on the planet since 1979. Melting sea ice is opening up paths for increased shipping and other vessel traffic in the region, especially along the Northern Sea Route, the Arctic shortcut between Europe and Asia that stretches more than 9,000 kilometres. The use of heavy fuel oil grew by 75 percent in the Arctic between 2015 and 2019.

articles.title: Tide against the fisherfolk
articles.author: Nabil Tahir
articles.summary: The Arabian Sea is warming more rapidly than many other regions of the global ocean. Sea surface temperatures in the northern Arabian Sea have risen by 0.7°C since the 1980s. Projections suggest temperatures could increase by 1.5°C to 2.0°C by 2100 under high-emission scenarios. Warming has serious implications for marine life. Small-scale fishermen in Balochistan are facing longer, more dangerous trips and suffering post-harvest losses estimated between 40 to 60%. Ocean acidification is emerging as a significant threat. Mangrove forests and mudflats are also deteriorating under climate pressure.

articles.title: The ocean is not just a carbon sink

The Seychelles is a member of the High Level Panel for a Sustainable Ocean Economy, which estimates that 35 percent of the emissions reductions needed by 2050 could come from the ocean.

articles.title: Extreme weather fuels pathogens and disease spread, study
articles.author: Syeda Fazeelat
articles.summary: Extreme weather fuels pathogens and disease spread, according to a recent study published in PLOS Climate. It analysed the impact of heatwaves on Daphnia magna or water fleas and a parasite, Ordospora colligata. It found that heatwaves adversely affected the parasite burden by nearly 13 times. The most extreme heat significantly decreased the number of parasites.

articles.title: Australia's south-east shivers through long weekend cold snap
articles.author: Emily Bennett
articles.summary: A cold snap is moving through Australia's south-east. It will remain icy in several parts of the country until Tuesday. Adelaide, Melbourne, Hobart and Canberra are looking at cold, wet and windy weather over the next few days. There will be heavy snow in some of Australia's alpine areas.

articles.summary: Jamaica is preparing for the general election. There is a plastic island in the Pacific Ocean that is larger than Jamaica.

articles.title: The IMF's Resilience and Sustainability Trust
articles.summary: Caribbean Small Island Developing States (SIDS) are on the front lines of climate change. They contribute little to global warming, but they are disproportionately affected by climate impacts. They are caught in a vicious 'debt-climate trap', where escalating climate costs deepen existing debt burdens. The world's wealthiest nations, who have historically contributed the most to climate change, must step up and honour their commitments.

articles.title: Labour Defence Review: Weak, Old Ideas & Likely Failure
articles.author: James Carter
articles.summary: Keir Starmer's recent defence plan focuses on bolstering traditional armed forces, but ignores climate-induced security risks. 77% of global hotspots experiencing violent conflict are also highly vulnerable to climate change impacts. The most significant security challenges of the 21st century are non-traditional. The UK's Joint Intelligence Committee should focus on climate security as a core area of focus.

articles.title: 'Climate Change: The Facts 2017' questions the prevailing narrative and encourages a more nuanced discussion on climate change
articles.author: Tags

It questions the prevailing narrative on climate change and encourages a more nuanced discussion. The book highlights the concept of natural climate cycles and the influence of natural factors like solar luminosity and lunar gravitational effects. It also challenges the mainstream narrative on the physics of carbon dioxide.
